- removed load load the glance-registry config. We load sql connection
  in common code now.

glance/db/sqlalchemy/api.py
- removed functions _wrap_db_error(), _is_db_connection_error(),
  _get_maker(), get_engine(), _ping_listener() and config
  `sql_connection_opt`. We have all these thigs in module
  `glance.openstack.common.db.sqlalchemy`.
- modified functions setup_db_env(), add_cli_options(), clear_db_env().
- functions _get_session() and get_engine() now call same functions
  from module `glance.openstack.common.db.sqlalchemy`.
- replaced sqlalchemy exception `sqlalchemy.exc.IntegrityError` to
  database duplicate exception - `db_exc.DBDuplicateEntry`.

Removed redundant tests - we use common code , so a lot of features was
already tested in Oslo.

Global variable _ENGINE was replaced by common function get_engine().

commit_message:
Use common Oslo database session

Use common oslo database code for work with session, connection, engines
instead of glance implementations.
Work with config options modified due to new common code config.
Removed unused glance code and tests for it.

Details:

glance/cmd/manage.py
- removed load load the glance-registry config. We load sql connection
  in common code now.

glance/db/sqlalchemy/api.py
- removed functions _wrap_db_error(), _is_db_connection_error(),
  _get_maker(), get_engine(), _ping_listener() and config
  `sql_connection_opt`. We have all these thigs in module
  `glance.openstack.common.db.sqlalchemy`.
- modified functions setup_db_env(), add_cli_options(), clear_db_env().
- functions _get_session() and get_engine() now call same functions
  from module `glance.openstack.common.db.sqlalchemy`.
- replaced sqlalchemy exception `sqlalchemy.exc.IntegrityError` to
  database duplicate exception - `db_exc.DBDuplicateEntry`.

Removed redundant tests - we use common code , so a lot of features was
already tested in Oslo.

Global variable _ENGINE was replaced by common function get_engine().

DocImpact
New database config options came from Oslo. See Table below
-------------------------------------------------------------------

-----------------------------|-------------------------------------
       Glance                | Oslo
-----------------------------|-------------------------------------
[DEFAULT] sql_connection     |  [database] connection
[DEFAULT] sql_idle_timeout   |  [database] idle_timeout

commit_message:
Enforce grouping like imports together

This rule (H307) enforces that all imports from a given type are
kept together.  Separating them with unnecessary whitespace goes
against the import guidelines and breaks our alphabetical order
checking.

Change-Id: I80721599a63e2f323d17d25822a167e44f566164

commit_message:
Enforce import grouping

This is a new hacking rule (H305) that enforces the hacking
guideline about grouping stdlib, third-party, and project
imports together.  It assumes any imports that are not found are
third party so the tool can be run in environments without all of
a project's deps installed.  This should be safe because stdlib
and project imports should always be available.

Change-Id: I1cfa85745e4da3e773296d623ba390c5edd11ef5

commit_message:
Removes privilege modification for MYSQL_BASE_DIR

Reasons:
- No usage of the path MYSQL_BASE_DIR in the method.
- 2 Files used in the method are both in different locations
  /tmp/my.cnf.tmp and /etc/mysql/my.cnf
- It is just a hanging line of code without any reasons.

Changes:
- privilege modification line removed from code.

Change-Id: I676f7faaf1e7b78c5d0f9f79b622f230ae2b9740
Closes-Bug: #1261854

commit_message:
downversion netaddr to 0.7.3

newer versions of pip will not download insecure/external packages.
see - https://github.com/pypa/pip/pull/1055

install/tests error out on pip 1.5

commit_message:
VMware: clean up unnecessary help message of options

Configuration options were grouped into [vmware]. So we don't need
point out that these options are used only for vmwareapi.VMwareESXDriver
or vmwareapi.VMwareVCDriver. This patch also corrects docstring for
vCenter related classes.

Change-Id: I77d95250ce1351bad60664ec7313d8e18d76332a

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-26 21:10:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Start of new developer documentation

There is currently no useful developer-focused documentation in-tree
for Neutron. There are a smattering of useful documents on the
OpenStack wiki, however, there isn't a good organization to this
information, nor is there a condensed developer focus to a lot of it.
Some of the wiki pages are more proposals for features or bug fixes,
and there is a need for architecture, design, and code walk-through
documentation for Neutron to help with new (and existing) contribution.

This patch begins the process of adding developer documentation to Neutron.
It updates the main developer reference index.rst to pull in-line with what
Nova is doing, leaving some todo references for future patches. It also
adds a development.environment tutorial that is up-to-date with current
Neutron development, using tox/testr processes for running unit tests and
including a number of references to external wiki pages that have
instructions for using DevStack for OpenStack contribution/testing.

The next series of patches will add automodule documentation to the
developer reference for some of the major modules in Neutron.

Change-Id: I23aaa11d9a174f24242c49767b92540f5e25b48a
Addresses: blueprint quantum-developer-docs

commit_message:
Start of new developer documentation

There is currently no useful developer-focused documentation in-tree
for Neutron. There are a smattering of useful documents on the
OpenStack wiki, however, there isn't a good organization to this
information, nor is there a condensed developer focus to a lot of it.
Some of the wiki pages are more proposals for features or bug fixes,
and there is a need for architecture, design, and code walk-through
documentation for Neutron to help with new (and existing) contribution.

This patch begins the process of adding developer documentation to Neutron.
It updates the main developer reference index.rst to pull in-line with what
Nova is doing, leaving some todo references for future patches. It also
adds a development.environment tutorial that is up-to-date with current
Neutron development, using tox/testr processes for running unit tests and
including a number of references to external wiki pages that have
instructions for using DevStack for OpenStack contribution/testing.

The next series of patches will add automodule documentation to the
developer reference for some of the major modules in Neutron.

Change-Id: I23aaa11d9a174f24242c49767b92540f5e25b48a
Addresses: blueprint quantum-developer-docs

commit_message:
Fix inconsistent result on identify_stack()

The result is inconsistent on identify_stack() for show a deleted stack:
1. show a deleted stack by stack_id, the result is returned.
2. show a deleted stack by stack_name, "StackNotFound" exception is
raised.

The result should be consistent of showing a deleted stack.

Change-Id: I24e65d7d569175c6d652b7fd9870b3cd0c4ee741
Closes-Bug: #1264933

commit_message:
Add additional metadata as key-value pairs in 3PAR

Track status of openstack volumes on 3PAR through
additional metadata added as key-value pairs. During volume attach
and detach, corresponding instance metadata is updated onto the
cinder volumes.

Change-Id: Iea8d2f26555e6be60001bf73755cae42446afec6
Closes-Bug: #1258033

subject: LVM: Activate Thin Pool LV upon initialization
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-13 15:45:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'LVM: Activate Thin Pool LV upon initialization

If the LVM thin pool is not active, space calculation fails,
as data_percent is not known.  Activate the pool upon initialization,
since we intend to use it anyway.

Slightly refactors _get_thin_pool_free_space so that it is clear
which missing/unexpected value is breaking things if a similar error
occurs for some other reason.

Closes-Bug: #1260773

Change-Id: I7cb187746c1ac297b82254c6efa37ba1c5fbb3e1
', 'number': 1}, {'created': '2013-12-13 15:45:18.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/brick/local_dev/lvm.py'], 'message': 'LVM: Activate Thin Pool LV upon initialization

If the LVM thin pool is not active, space calculation fails,
as data_percent is not known.  Activate the pool upon initialization,
since we intend to use it anyway.

Slightly refactors _get_thin_pool_free_space so that it is clear
which missing/unexpected value is breaking things if a similar error
occurs for some other reason.

Closes-Bug: #1260773

Change-Id: I7cb187746c1ac297b82254c6efa37ba1c5fbb3e1
', 'number': 2}]
commit_message:
LVM: Activate Thin Pool LV upon initialization

If the LVM thin pool is not active, space calculation fails,
as data_percent is not known.  Activate the pool upon initialization,
since we intend to use it anyway.

Slightly refactors _get_thin_pool_free_space so that it is clear
which missing/unexpected value is breaking things if a similar error
occurs for some other reason.

Closes-Bug: #1260773

Change-Id: I7cb187746c1ac297b82254c6efa37ba1c5fbb3e1

subject: DONT MERGE: Convert Token KVS backend to new KeyValueStore Impl
revisions:
[{'created': '2014-01-02 23:09:06.000000000', 'files': ['keystone/token/backends/kvs.py', 'keystone/tests/test_backend_kvs.py', 'keystone/tests/test_backend_memcache.py', 'keystone/tests/test_backend.py'], 'message': 'DONT MERGE: Convert Token KVS backend to new KeyValueStore Impl

This is testing this patchset and should not be merged.  This is
meant to test without changing the patchset order.

This patchset converts the current token KVS backend to the new
dogpile.cache based KeyValueStore implementation.  The changeset
provides the same public interface as the previous KVS driver but
drastically reworks the internal mechanisms to be more similar to
the memcache based driver so that direct access to the in-mem db
is not required to effectively use the KeyValueStore.

Change-Id: I0cbfc43c35c4b3d367e8c5f1947f21f9fbb39583
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
DONT MERGE: Convert Token KVS backend to new KeyValueStore Impl

This is testing this patchset and should not be merged.  This is
meant to test without changing the patchset order.

This patchset converts the current token KVS backend to the new
dogpile.cache based KeyValueStore implementation.  The changeset
provides the same public interface as the previous KVS driver but
drastically reworks the internal mechanisms to be more similar to
the memcache based driver so that direct access to the in-mem db
is not required to effectively use the KeyValueStore.

Change-Id: I0cbfc43c35c4b3d367e8c5f1947f21f9fbb39583

commit_message:
Install Guide: Fix SUSE neutron-server setup

On SLES and openSUSE the neutron-server service is called
openstack-neutron.

Change-Id: I426dbb131b570750508c3e1b0fa2d2c892c51a91

The db_backend should be deprecated. See also the diff here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/34671/17/nova/openstack/common/db/api.py The two backends should be distinguished. commit_message:
Duplicates in generated tables

In the table nova-db.xml, the backend and db_backend are duplicates in generated
tables. The db_backend should be deprecated.

See also the diff here:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/34671/17/nova/openstack/common/db/api.py

The two backends should be distinguished.

Change-Id: I7b53a95a4d79bbe52041f39a06653e0a0fcb6523
Closes-Bug:#1226464

', 'number': 1}, {'created': '2013-12-29 10:50:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Convert build_and_run_instance to objects

This change involved refactoring a number of test helpers so they know
whether to create stubs for an object version or a traditional version of
a test scenario. The conditional logic here will be removed when all of
the compute manager is converted to objects.

This also means that drivers now receive an instance object for
their spawn call.

Related to blueprint icehouse-objects.
Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects.

Change-Id: If726f19441c33bbc59e8cd116ef983557fae9943

commit_message:
Convert nova.compute.manager's _spawn to objects

This means that drivers now receive an instance object for
their spawn call.

Related to blueprint icehouse-objects.
Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects.

Change-Id: If726f19441c33bbc59e8cd116ef983557fae9943

commit_message:
port admin/test_servers* into Nova V3 tests part1

This changeset only copies the v2 files into the appropriate v3
directories unchanged. This is being tried in order to make
reviewing of the porting easier as gerrit will display only what
is actually changed for v3 rather than entirely new files.

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api-tests

Change-Id: Ic32acc0fff4b98287f27b5bcf3475b6a3b457c31
Closes-Bug: #1259056

subject: Increase exception log details
revisions:
[{'created': '2014-01-02 10:33:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Increase exception log details

Add informative message to log, as the exception is logged by default

Replaces:
except Exception as exc:
    LOG.exception(exc)

With:
except Exception:
    LOG.exception("[Description of the failed operation]")

Closes bug 1262547

Change-Id: I97cd13e4b32df9a3f9b2e7e1f8946a6a4e0aed3f
', 'number': 1}, {'created': '2014-01-02 10:35:15.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/api/volume/test_volumes_list.py', 'tempest/api/compute/base.py', 'tempest/thirdparty/boto/test.py', 'tempest/api/compute/images/test_images_oneserver_negative.py', 'tempest/scenario/test_network_basic_ops.py', 'tempest/api/compute/images/test_list_image_filters.py', 'tempest/api/compute/images/test_images_oneserver.py'], 'message': 'Increase exception log details

Add informative message to log, as the exception is logged by default

    LOG.exception(exc)

commit_message:
Increase exception log details

Add informative message to log, as the exception is logged by default

Replaces:
except Exception as exc:
    LOG.exception(exc)

With:
except Exception:
    LOG.exception("[Description of the failed operation]")

Closes-bug: #1262547

Change-Id: I97cd13e4b32df9a3f9b2e7e1f8946a6a4e0aed3f

subject: Add a db check for CHARSET=utf8
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-19 23:34:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Add a db check for CHARSET=utf8

This is to prevent confusing migration errrors caused by

commit_message:
Kill finally, use addCleanUp

Remove the finally usage for cleanup in the floating_ips tests and
in the test_services tests.

The finally blocks may try to delete resources which are even does not
exists, and or referencing to an undefined variables, which could hide
the original exceptions from the resource creation operations.

Change-Id: I23740553c793dcb2904a561b8f2ce801137e32d8

unique token that enforces idempotency for RunInstance calls.
If a client token exists, DescribeInstances will return it wrapped

Closes-Bug: #1260853
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Return client tokens in EC2 DescribeInstances

EC2 instances can be instantiated with a client token, a per-instance
unique token that enforces idempotency for RunInstance calls.
If a client token exists, DescribeInstances will return it wrapped
in <clientToken></clientToken>.

Change-Id: I1deb2c0666d0274ed3c181ecb0e0dc65112605ec
Closes-Bug: #1260853

commit_message:
Add boolean convertors for migrate_live API

migrate_live API contains "block_migration" and "disk_over_commit" as
the parameters. They should be boolean.
There are the other boolean parameters such as "on_shared_storage" of
evacuate API, they can be passed with either boolean or string(e.g. "True").
For API consistency, this patch adds boolean convertors to migrate_live
API.

Change-Id: Ic3040811977c834bfd4b0b4527795382e11227ed
Closes-Bug: #1257661

commit_message:
Adds a PREPARED state after baremetal node power on.

During a baremetal deployment there is a middle step which
is not currently represented. If the baremetal node powers on
but never connects to the deploy-helper, it is impossible to tell
from the database whether the deploy environment was not created
or whether the machine is dead.

Change-Id: I6be3d45fee28970cbb02945c518be34b2bc74689
Closes-Bug: #1184470

commit_message:
Move and rename ValidTypes

Move the ValidTypes class from v1/utils.py to the v1/types.py file which
should contain everything related to wsme types in our API.

This patch also renames the ValidTypes class to MultiType because
it reflects better what this type about, it's a type that validates
multiple types and is more consistent with the other types names: Ending
with the word "Type" (singular).

Change-Id: I5ea5968bc3969f081bdf314771111e904462d195

commit_message:
Convert trycmd() to oslo's processutils

trycmd() have been moved into oslo and is already imported in Ironic,
this patch changes our custom trycmd() function to use the one from
oslo's processutils.

commit_message:
Add prepare, clean_up, take_over methods to deploy

Add three new methods to the deploy interface,
which will be used by the ConductorManager to trigger
(re)building of the deploy environment and updating of
external mappings/dependencies when rebalancing the hash ring.

Also refactors the PXE driver to utilize these new methods.

blueprint instance-mapping-by-consistent-hash

Change-Id: I1bebb895cbe29a7059a9873ef90ee039790c1031

commit_message:
Fixes .gitignore

Reasons:
- There were multiple gitignore files in repository.

Changes:
- All files merged into single .gitignore.
- log files are now covered by *.log so no separate log names needed.

Change-Id: Ia7fb4d925669cf92ceed6706e770e66ea87f5b81
Closes-Bug: #1260461

Last version of Swift tempurl MW allow HEAD request
even if PUT or GET are not allowed. This patch

commit_message:
Add test for HEAD queries on Swift tempurl MW

Last version of Swift tempurl MW allow HEAD request
even if PUT or GET are not allowed. This patch
tests that feature.
Related Swift commit: d18b6d8d5d6ca8c0adf3b98b488042c49394a072

This patch also provides some code refactoring to the
middleware.

Change-Id: I33a3f73cf61a0c044428f885154feccb93c672ac

commit_message:
Fix checkmount  error parsing in swift-recon

- swift-recon now handles parsing instances where 'mounted' key (in unmounted
  and disk_usage) is an error message instead of a bool.
- Add's checkmount exception handling to the recon umounted endpoint.
- Updates existing unittest to have ismount throw an error.
- Updates unittests to cover the corner cases

Change-Id: Id51d14a8b98de69faaac84b2b34b7404b7df69e9

commit_message:
Do not use ndash in filenames

Ndashes in filenames will cause problems with some filesystems
and also showed a bug in pbr when running tox.

Note that none of these files was actually used.
There is already a copy without the ndashes in common/figures.

Related-Bug: #1265622

Change-Id: Iff5409daaa8b6e62ab59902e7c47914540a0321c

commit_message:
Nova aggregate-details should be more human friendly

'nova aggregate-details' shows Hosts, Availability Zone
and Metadata in the python unicode notation.

+ Adds some tests about aggregates ported from v1 to the
  v3 shell

commit_message:
Expose the rebuild preserve-ephemeral extension

This new extension permits preserving the ephemeral partition if the
Nova hypervisor supports that. This is primarily useful when Cinder is
not available to provide preservation of state while replacing the
image in use. One common situation for that is Nova Baremetal.

DocImpact
Blueprint: baremetal-preserve-ephemeral
Partial-Bug: #1174154
Co-Authored-By: Robert Collins <rbtcollins@hp.com>
Change-Id: Ib1511653904d4f95ab03fb471669175127004582

token should be used for everything. This assumption is correct for the
endpoint/token case but not in the auth_url/token case where you will
want to fetch a new token.

There are still problems such as if you use auth_url/token
authentication then refreshing the token will not change the expiry, but
it is still better than the original method.

commit_message:
Correctly handle auth_url/token authentication

Previously the client assumed that if a user passed a token then this
token should be used for everything. This assumption is correct for the
endpoint/token case but not in the auth_url/token case where you will
want to fetch a new token. This is needed in the case where you want to
use an existing token to fetch a token that is re-scoped or activate a
trust.

There are still problems such as if you use auth_url/token
authentication then when the token expires it will try to refresh it,
but authenticating with a token will not extend the token expiry.

Closes-Bug: #1257541
Change-Id: I1c35600ca5437da44071dcea5361bfb42f6b72a3

commit_message:
XenAPI: Fix bug with Xen ext4-using guests

Ubuntu saucy is using ext4, which means it hits a barrier
bug with certain versions of Xen, leading to a read only
filesystem.

This is bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/824089

Change-Id: I9a72b203d473dc555324d44ad7c240c80dccda15

commit_message:
Change the libvirtd log level to DEBUG

Gate tests fail sometimes due to libvirt problems, but it is difficult
to investigate their reasons or workarounds because there is not any
log about libvirt.
This patch changes the log level of libvirtd to DEBUG for investigating
libvirt problems.

Change-Id: Ib6559ff978fa813d0332f2339d241dd3437196ee
Related-Bug: #1254872

commit_message:
Add missing egress sec group for all tcp/udp/icmp

When creating "Security Group Egress ALL TCP/UDP/ICMP", the
direction is always Ingress, need to add egress in the situation.

Fixes bug #1254040

Change-Id: I1a2bdc07d7ca4ecc12ebdb35a1f357de0d09c502

commit_message:
Add a package mapping for libvirt-dev

This is a dependency for the libvirt-python Python package that
ceilometer-agent-compute uses. libvirt-python is already installed globally in
the system via apt/yum, but that's not available to ceilometer-agent-compute's
virtualenv.

Change-Id: I07a12226889c6cda3bd04021240ee9714a396522

commit_message:
Initialize underlying database files

Packages will not necessarily agree with the settings we have made. This
ensures that before we store any data, we set up the InnoDB data files
and permissions properly.

Change-Id: Ie743f4f4f44a95cead11e6b9856bdfe3ce734b74

subject: Added step to check for /etc/neutron/plugin.ini symlink
revisions:
[{'created': '2014-01-02 10:24:30.000000000', 'files': ['doc/install-guide/section_neutron-install.xml'], 'message': "Added step to check for /etc/neutron/plugin.ini symlink

I added a step to check for a symlink /etc/neutron/plugin.ini pointing
to the associated plug-in configuration file. Should the symlink not
exist, this step also contains instructions for creating it using Open
vSwitch as an example. This patch applies to configuring Neutron on
a controller and network node, but not a compute node since it doesn't
run the Neutron server daemon.

This patch now covers SLES and derivatives too which expect the
NEUTRON_PLUGIN_CONF variable in the /etc/sysconfig/neutron file to
reference the associated plug-in configuration file. Thanks Andreas!

Change-Id: I0ad19d479129d68543adfd65268f8925e7f0b272
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: #1260173
(cherry picked from commit b3bd8fe9b9b27f43a7c17cbc49f4ce6bd476a4fa)
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Added step to check for /etc/neutron/plugin.ini symlink

I added a step to check for a symlink /etc/neutron/plugin.ini pointing
to the associated plug-in configuration file. Should the symlink not
exist, this step also contains instructions for creating it using Open
vSwitch as an example. This patch applies to configuring Neutron on
a controller and network node, but not a compute node since it doesn't
run the Neutron server daemon.

This patch now covers SLES and derivatives too which expect the
NEUTRON_PLUGIN_CONF variable in the /etc/sysconfig/neutron file to
reference the associated plug-in configuration file. Thanks Andreas!

Change-Id: I0ad19d479129d68543adfd65268f8925e7f0b272
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: #1260173
(cherry picked from commit b3bd8fe9b9b27f43a7c17cbc49f4ce6bd476a4fa)

commit_message:
Fix the path of memcached config file

On CentOS, the correct location of memcached is
/etc/sysconfig/memcached (without .conf).

Closes-bug: #1265403
Change-Id: Idaac8920c1954d917fe533031fb0ff2416d5b339

commit_message:

Per the mailing list thread, introducing Rubocop as a replacement for Tailor.
Assuming Jenkins likes this, more pedantic patches will follow to make Rubocop

commit_message:
Setup for openstack-doc-tools gating

Add files to allow us gating via:
tox -e checkbuild
tox -e checkniceness
etc

Enhance .gitignore to ignore files used by gating and by more
editors.

Change-Id: Id33d04f734d438d01dd5bbd784abaa213de5dbc9

[{'created': '2013-12-31 03:17:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Enhance message for watch rule

commit_message:
Enhance message for watch rule

When heat engine log message for watch rule, it will log message
as following:
WATCH: stack:86ef85cb-994c-4481-bb4d-2bb556236dbd,
watch_name:a1-MEMAlarmHigh ALARM

We should update it to:
WATCH: stack:86ef85cb-994c-4481-bb4d-2bb556236dbd,
watch_name:a1-MEMAlarmHigh, new_state:ALARM

This patch also enables I18N for this log message.

Change-Id: I23a825a8b5bed621c7d3fc3e582e853e52a3e69d

commit_message:
Update openstack-common.conf list, sync with oslo (0d8f18b)

All modules in use here should be listed in openstack-common.conf,
so that all of them are updated to a common code revision when
an oslo sync happens (otherwise it will likely cause subtle
bugs for those oslo modules that become slightly incompatible
between each other).

Change-Id: I9be5a9becb25a734674e2ef44f73694b01d1e16f

commit_message:
Added configuration for /etc/neutron/neutron.conf

for configuring OVS plugin we need to configure the neutron.conf file
as per the configuration of /etc/neutron/neutron.conf for installation
of neutron on controller node. for neutron installation on compute node,
only auth_uri setting is missing in the configuration of
/etc/neutron/neutron.conf that i have added.

Closes-Bug:#1246068

Change-Id: I0628f65202dacf34997ec8ea6552b5b6faddbc69
backport: havana

commit_message:
Do not merge, debug for TempestConfig() on import

This commit just adds tracebacks when TempestConfig() is run to find
the source of config on import.

commit_message:
Remove redundant word from OS::Nova::Server

All parameters not marked as "Required" are optional. The documentation
generated from the schemas will already note this, so having the word in
the description is redundant.

Change-Id: I1df10c598969e97d5c1c8ecd1c2896a59ae1d2d1
Closes-Bug: #1225845

subject: MariaDB backend support
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-25 17:45:33.000000000', 'files': ['lib/databases/mysql', 'lib/database', 'stack.sh'], 'message': 'MariaDB backend support

* Allows mariadb to be installed and configured as a database backend
by modifying the lib/databases/mysql backend file as MariaDB is a drop-in
but compatible replacement of the MySQL database
* mysql should be disabled in the localrc file or removed
from ENABLED_SERVICES and replaced with mariadb

Change-Id: I810e2ccfb981293de2fe63bfa7407ec1cb0e4ef8
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
MariaDB backend support

* Allows mariadb to be installed and configured as a database backend
by modifying the lib/databases/mysql backend file as MariaDB is a drop-in
but compatible replacement of the MySQL database
* mysql should be disabled in the localrc file or removed
from ENABLED_SERVICES and replaced with mariadb

Change-Id: I810e2ccfb981293de2fe63bfa7407ec1cb0e4ef8

commit_message:
Avoid a race when associating instance_uuid

Current code can potentially overwrite the instance_uuid without
exception when multiple dbapi.update_node calls are issued. This
patch adds a check to dbapi so that the NodeAssociated exception
will be raised in this case.
The Nova Ironic driver will handle this exception. This will be
introduced in a separate patch.

Change-Id: I28ef5ce55399bde7073ffc111e9bc4400e5577ee
Partial-Bug: #1244541

commit_message:
Remove usage of mox class

We have a base test class already that does the cleaning, we don't need
to use mox base class, which uses a different pattern for the stub
object.

Change-Id: I5fce772bd330f9fb0fca5821ab200b55c0fb7358

commit_message:
Improve error handling in validate_vendor_action

validate_vendor_action method of conductor may be used for validate
callback data from deploy/maintenance ramdisk, error message not
saved in Ironic for this case.
This patch adds saving for error message to node.last_error.

Change-Id: Ic01a6f9a95c7e09e7ce7925dad9a7fd228de65bd

commit_message:
Fix key error in adapter caused by changed api

Nailgun Api repsonse for api/cluster/id has been changed
as result OSTF filed with key error
Fix this issue in adapter mixin and ostf config.py

Change-Id: I73b5a5075ec14414a8b28c2c47d023ccc126b7ae
Closes-Bug: # 1265029

commit_message:
Fix empty network deletion in db_base_plugin for postgresql

Need to disable joined loads for port query in delete_network
as in other methods.

No unit test is being added, because the problem is not reproducible with
sqlite.

Closes-Bug: #1261652

Change-Id: I7a015be6f2f9b8ae43bc29a767d16af30120f13f

commit_message:
Remove any accidental extra /etc/my.cnf

Some platforms have packages that install /etc/my.cnf which would not
work well with our element which wants the configs in /etc/mysql.

Change-Id: Ifda1cca7287fae37eb8587598f5fab60228d8e99

Remove mysql debian-sys-maint user

The way we build and install the package prevents this user from
being created and we don't need it anyway. Also this makes no sense
on Fedora/RHEL/SuSE.

Change-Id: Ib22388a660303065b93c3b284c1359b71faeeab8

commit_message:
Make mysql.create-users section optional

Before this change, if it was not passed in the script that reads it
would error out because a single newline is not valid JSON.

commit_message:
Disallow negative image sizes

Currently Glance v1 allows creation of images with negative sizes when
the source URL provided by the --location parmeter does not exist at
the time of creation.

There is already a check to verify whether or not an image size can be
converted to an int but the check doesn't verify whether or not the
resulting value is >= 0. This commit supplements that check to
disallow negative values for the size parameter.

Change-Id: I47511f3e34cf5adfdf944747d94285ecbbda4249
Closes-Bug: #1260738

commit_message:
Use WithScenarios base class instead of load_tests

To support test scenarios, we now override load_tests in the module
using them. To support alternate test runners and not needing that, the
patch makes the Heat test base class inherit testsceanios.WithScenarios.

Change-Id: Ie2435e41c466c0687bb1dd95080dcac7c837aaba

commit_message:
Cleanup object usage in the delete path

This patch cleans up some dict-like usage of instances in the compute
api path, as well as removes a redundant direct call to fetch the
instance's system_metadata.

Related to blueprint icehouse-objects

subject: Added step to check for /etc/neutron/plugin.ini symlink
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-31 21:55:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Added step to check for /etc/neutron/plugin.ini symlink

I added a step to check for a symlink /etc/neutron/plugin.ini pointing
to the associated plug-in configuration file. Should the symlink not
exist, this step also contains instructions for creating it using Open
vSwitch as an example. This patch applies to configuring Neutron on
a controller and network node, but not a compute node since it doesn't
run the Neutron server daemon.

I wrote this patch with RHEL and derivatives in mind. However, it may
also apply to SLES and derivatives. I would appreciate if someone
familiar with the latter can confirm whether or not this patch applies
to them.

Change-Id: I0ad19d479129d68543adfd65268f8925e7f0b272
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: #1260173
", 'number': 1}, {'created': '2014-01-01 16:47:06.000000000', 'files': ['doc/install-guide/section_neutron-install.xml'], 'message': "Added step to check for /etc/neutron/plugin.ini symlink

I added a step to check for a symlink /etc/neutron/plugin.ini pointing
to the associated plug-in configuration file. Should the symlink not
exist, this step also contains instructions for creating it using Open
vSwitch as an example. This patch applies to configuring Neutron on
a controller and network node, but not a compute node since it doesn't
run the Neutron server daemon.

This patch now covers SLES and derivatives too which expect the
NEUTRON_PLUGIN_CONF variable in the /etc/sysconfig/neutron file to
reference the associated plug-in configuration file. Thanks Andreas!

Change-Id: I0ad19d479129d68543adfd65268f8925e7f0b272
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: #1260173
", 'number': 2}]
commit_message:
Added step to check for /etc/neutron/plugin.ini symlink

I added a step to check for a symlink /etc/neutron/plugin.ini pointing
to the associated plug-in configuration file. Should the symlink not
exist, this step also contains instructions for creating it using Open
vSwitch as an example. This patch applies to configuring Neutron on
a controller and network node, but not a compute node since it doesn't
run the Neutron server daemon.

This patch now covers SLES and derivatives too which expect the
NEUTRON_PLUGIN_CONF variable in the /etc/sysconfig/neutron file to
reference the associated plug-in configuration file. Thanks Andreas!

Change-Id: I0ad19d479129d68543adfd65268f8925e7f0b272
backport: havana
Closes-Bug: #1260173

commit_message:
Permit detecting seed-up on remote virsh VMs.

Remote VMs do not show up the local MAC table, but our design for them
has out of band IP allocation via Neutron so we can use ping instead
to detect when it has successfully DHCP'd.

Change-Id: Ie7273d1d4213e8a49d0bcf10ecb05ec7d47b8bec

commit_message:
Remove the redundant code

In methods 'version_control' and 'db_sync' in glance/db/sqlalchemy/migration.py,
there are redundant code 'sql_connection = CONF.sql_connection'.
The 'sql_connection's are local variable and not used.

Change-Id: Ie8a12e6f385f7103463172ed9acde1de0336a6d4
Closes-Bug:#1264056

commit_message:
Removes vim configuration headers

 - Removes vim headers: It's not needed to set tabstop tons of times,
   this can be done by setting vimrc.
 - I did not update files in common/* and install_venv_common.py because
   these files are sync with oslo.

Note:
  - http://openstack.10931.n7.nabble.com/Remove-vim-modelines-td21780.html
  - work also started for gantt on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/64393/

Change-Id: Iada5e40ad44a0901e98c85743ddb13f0f0013f16

subject: Perform init() for each temporary user
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-03 17:02:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Perform init() for each temporary user

The init() mechanism that allowed to allocate resources in the cloud like
servers or floating ips has been broken since the introduction of temporary
tenants and users used during benchmarking due to the fact that resources
created from, say, an admin account could not be accessed by temporary users.

This patch repairs the issue by changing the way init() methods work. Here,
we call init() once for each of the temporary users which enables to allocate
resources for each of the temporary users and makes them available for access
during benchmarking.

Blueprint test-engine-init

Change-Id: Id57d8c2651f1fe711c82bffafb77636b2f3cd0b4
', 'number': 1}, {'created': '2013-12-10 12:20:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Perform init() for each temporary user

commit_message:
Perform init() for each temporary user

The init() mechanism that allowed to allocate resources in the cloud like
servers or floating ips has been broken since the introduction of temporary
tenants and users used during benchmarking due to the fact that resources
created from, say, an admin account could not be accessed by temporary users.

This patch repairs the issue by changing the way init() methods work. Here,
we call init() once for each of the temporary users which enables to allocate
resources for each of the temporary users and makes them available for access
during benchmarking.

Finally, slight UT refactoring is present here which replaces with-blocks for
mocks with the more appropriate decorator syntax.

Blueprint test-engine-init

Change-Id: Id57d8c2651f1fe711c82bffafb77636b2f3cd0b4

subject: Make openstack clients for temp users lazy
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-03 17:02:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Make openstack clients for temp users lazy

Here we change a bit the way openstack clients for temporary users are created
by the system, so that they get created only if needed for the purposes of some
scenario. This helps to save running time as e.g. keystone clients require some
time to authenticate.

commit_message:
Make openstack clients for temp users lazy

Here we change a bit the way openstack clients for temporary users are created
by the system, so that they get created only if needed for the purposes of some
scenario. This helps to save running time as e.g. keystone clients require some
time to authenticate.

Blueprint lazy-osclients

Change-Id: I2ef5e5ae75618dc3b84b093f50f0c843afa953f4

commit_message:
Add class for checking models with db(part I)

New class SyncModelsWithMigrations includes helper methods for
checking equality models with db. It has an opportunity for testing
of columns for each table.
Checked properties:
- data type,
- nullable,
- default values,
- primary key,
- unique,
- index.

It will be used by test for checking of equality models to migrations
state.

bp: sync-models-with-migrations
Change-Id: I58e7c6a6ba9455b352ad349aa4ebc8f8364d2d5d

subject: Add Volume ACL Permissions: Keystone backend
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-06 14:28:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Add Volume ACL Permissions: Keystone backend

Implementation:

Part 3. Volume ACL Keystone backend
    Add class to work with users and user groups data through Keystone.
    Not all the openstack deployments use Keystone as Identity Service.
    So it is used here by default, but you can implement your own class depending
    on another Identity Service and specify it in the config.

    Note, that in a class for work through Keystone Identity Service
    v2.0 keystone client is used as well as v3 keystone client.
    It's due to some functions are implemented in the only version of
    keystone client, e.g. users.check_in_group is implemented in v3
    version only and then we should use v3 keystone client, but
    there is no roles.roles_for_user or any analogs in v3 version,
    in v2.0 only, then we should use v2.0 version for checking
    user(other user, not user_id from context) is admin.
    This will be fixed when it's possible.

blueprint volume-acl

Change-Id: Ib69fa6dd78bb47280ec49e65de650de492194764

commit_message:
Add Volume ACL Permissions: Keystone backend

Implementation:

Part 3. Volume ACL Keystone backend
    Add class to work with users and user groups data through Keystone.
    Not all the openstack deployments use Keystone as Identity Service.
    So it is used here by default, but you can implement your own class depending
    on another Identity Service and specify it in the config.

    Note, that in a class for work through Keystone Identity Service
    v2.0 keystone client is used as well as v3 keystone client.
    It's due to some functions are implemented in the only version of
    keystone client, e.g. users.check_in_group is implemented in v3
    version only and then we should use v3 keystone client, but
    there is no roles.roles_for_user or any analogs in v3 version,
    in v2.0 only, then we should use v2.0 version for checking
    user(other user, not user_id from context) is admin.
    This will be fixed when it's possible.

blueprint volume-acl

Change-Id: Ib69fa6dd78bb47280ec49e65de650de492194764

Change-Id: I7e04f31e32ce882241726776c79e14a151a79325
', 'number': 10}, {'created': '2013-08-22 23:59:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Add Volume ACL Permissions

ACL implementation brings a mechanism of access permission management into
Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,
which is full aceess(The user can do any operations on the volume.).
If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and
the users with super authoritzations, like administrators.
With ACL implementation, it is possible for different users to have different
levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish
a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a single user, a group of users, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission can be classifies as the following:

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
	Indicated as 1.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
	This permission includes Read permission.
	Indicated as 2.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
	Indicated as 3.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level. This permission includes Permission Read.
	Indicated as 4.
Read+Permission Read: Indicated as 5.
Write+Permission Read: Indicated as 6.
Full access: This permission inludes all the other permissions and
	equals to Write+Permission Write.
	Indicated as 7.

Implementation:

1. Add a new table called VolumeACLPermission with columns:
    id - the primary key of the row;
    volume_id - indicates volume's ID;
    user_or_group_id - indicates a user or group ID which the permission
    affects or 'everyone' keyword for all users;
    type - "user" means user_or_group_id is user_id; "group" means
    user_or_group_id is group_id;
    access_permission - indicates access permission level. (from 1 to 7 as
    described in Access Permission above)

    Use cases:
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Write access to user_id2. The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 1, volume_id: 'volume_id1', user_or_group_id: 'user_id2', type:
        'user', access_permission: 2}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read access to all users(everyone). The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 2, volume_id: 'volume_id1', user_or_group_id: 'everyone', type:
        'user', access_permission: 1}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read+Permission Read access to all the users
    in a group(group_id1). The corresponding record:
        {id: 3, volume_id: 'volume_id1', user_or_group_id: 'group_id1', type:
        'group', access_permission: 5}
2. CRUD for VolumeACLPermission.
3. Add os-volume-acl API extension.
    Use cases:
    * create/update permission:
        POST /v2/<project_id>/os-volume-acl
        {'body':
            'volume_acl_permission': {
                 'volume_id': <volume_id>,
                 'type': 'user', # or 'group'
                 'user_or_group_id': <user_or_group_id>,
                 'access_permission': <1-7>,
            }
        }
    * show permission (by permission ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>
    * list all permissions(for all the volumes for which the user has
    'Permission Read' access) or for a volume (by volume ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * get access permission level for the volume ID:
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/access?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * delete permission:
        DELETE /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>

blueprint volume-acl

If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and

With ACL implementation, it is possible for different users to have different
levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish
a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a single user, a group of users, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission can be classifies as the following:

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
	Indicated as 1.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
	This permission includes Read permission.
	Indicated as 2.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
	Indicated as 3.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level. This permission includes Permission Read.
	Indicated as 4.
Read+Permission Read: Indicated as 5.
Write+Permission Read: Indicated as 6.
Full access: This permission inludes all the other permissions and
	equals to Write+Permission Write.
	Indicated as 7.
Read+Permission Write: Indicated as 8.

Implementation:

Part 3. API extension
    Add os-volume-acl API extension.
    Use cases:
    * create/update permission:
        POST /v2/<project_id>/os-volume-acl
        {'body':
            'volume_acl_permission': {
                 'volume_id': <volume_id>,
                 'type': 'user', # or 'group'
                 'user_or_group_id': <user_or_group_id>,
                 'access_permission': <1-7>,
            }
        }
    * show permission (by permission ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>
    * list all permissions(for all the volumes for which the user has
    'Permission Read' access) or for a volume (by volume ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * get access permission level for the volume ID:
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/access?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * delete permission:
        DELETE /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>

ACL implementation brings a mechanism of access permission management into
Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,
which is full access(The user can do any operations on the volume.).
If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and
the users with super authoritzations, like administrators.
With ACL implementation, it is possible for different users to have different
levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full

The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --

The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a single user, a group of users, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission represents as an integer, which bits are mapped to:
1st(most significant) bit -- Permission Write;
2nd -- Permission Read;
3rd -- Write;
4th -- Read.
Where

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level.

Implementation:

Part 3. API extension
    Add os-volume-acl API extension.
    Use cases:
    * create/update permission:
        POST /v2/<project_id>/os-volume-acl
        {'body':
            'volume_acl_permission': {
                 'volume_id': <volume_id>,
                 'type': 'user', # or 'group'
                 'entity_id': <entity_id>,
                 'access_permission': <1-7>,
            }
        }
    * show permission (by permission ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>
    * list all permissions(for all the volumes for which the user has
    'Permission Read' access) or for a volume (by volume ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * get access permission level for the volume ID:
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/access?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * delete permission:
        DELETE /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>

commit_message:
Add Volume ACL Permissions: API extension

Implementation:
Part 4. API extension
    Add os-volume-acl API extension.
    Use cases:
    * create/update permission:
        POST /v2/<project_id>/os-volume-acl
        {'body':
            'volume_acl_permission': {
                 'volume_id': <volume_id>,
                 'type': 'project', # or 'group'
                 'entity_id': <entity_id>,
                 'access_permission': <access_permission>,
            }
        }
    * show permission (by permission ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>
    * list all permissions(for all the volumes for which the user has
    'Permission Read' access) or for a volume (by volume ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * get access permission level for the volume ID:
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/access?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * delete permission:
        DELETE /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>

blueprint volume-acl

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-23 12:51:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Add Volume ACL Permissions: Volume ACL API

ACL implementation brings a mechanism of access permission management into
Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,
which is full aceess(The user can do any operations on the volume.).
If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and
the users with super authoritzations, like administrators.
With ACL implementation, it is possible for different users to have different
levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish
a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a single user, a group of users, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission can be classifies as the following:

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
	Indicated as 1.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
	This permission includes Read permission.
	Indicated as 2.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
	Indicated as 3.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level. This permission includes Permission Read.
	Indicated as 4.
Read+Permission Read: Indicated as 5.
Write+Permission Read: Indicated as 6.
Full access: This permission inludes all the other permissions and
	equals to Write+Permission Write.
	Indicated as 7.
Read+Permission Write: Indicated as 8.

Implementation:

1. Add a new table called VolumeACLPermission with columns:
    id - the primary key of the row;
    volume_id - indicates volume's ID;
    user_or_group_id - indicates a user or group ID which the permission
    affects or 'everyone' keyword for all users;
    type - "user" means user_or_group_id is user_id; "group" means
    user_or_group_id is group_id;
    access_permission - indicates access permission level. (from 1 to 7 as
    described in Access Permission above)

    Use cases:
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Write access to user_id2. The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 1, volume_id: 'volume_id1', user_or_group_id: 'user_id2', type:
        'user', access_permission: 2}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read access to all users(everyone). The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 2, volume_id: 'volume_id1', user_or_group_id: 'everyone', type:
        'user', access_permission: 1}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read+Permission Read access to all the users
    in a group(group_id1). The corresponding record:
        {id: 3, volume_id: 'volume_id1', user_or_group_id: 'group_id1', type:
        'group', access_permission: 5}
2. CRUD for VolumeACLPermission.
3. Add os-volume-acl API extension.
    Use cases:
    * create/update permission:
        POST /v2/<project_id>/os-volume-acl
        {'body':
            'volume_acl_permission': {
                 'volume_id': <volume_id>,
                 'type': 'user', # or 'group'
                 'user_or_group_id': <user_or_group_id>,
                 'access_permission': <1-7>,
            }
        }
    * show permission (by permission ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>
    * list all permissions(for all the volumes for which the user has
    'Permission Read' access) or for a volume (by volume ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * get access permission level for the volume ID:
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/access?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * delete permission:
        DELETE /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>

blueprint volume-acl

Change-Id: I1537e1462ddb08f72b32b96a085e3ed98efaad48

', 'number': 2}, {'created': '2013-08-23 14:11:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Add Volume ACL Permissions: Volume ACL Module

ACL implementation brings a mechanism of access permission management into
Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,
which is full aceess(The user can do any operations on the volume.).
If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and
the users with super authoritzations, like administrators.
With ACL implementation, it is possible for different users to have different
levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish
a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a single user, a group of users, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission can be classifies as the following:

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
	Indicated as 1.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
	This permission includes Read permission.
	Indicated as 2.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
	Indicated as 3.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level. This permission includes Permission Read.
	Indicated as 4.
Read+Permission Read: Indicated as 5.
Write+Permission Read: Indicated as 6.
Full access: This permission inludes all the other permissions and
	equals to Write+Permission Write.
	Indicated as 7.
Read+Permission Write: Indicated as 8.

Implementation:

Part 2. Volume ACL Module
    Add CRUD for VolumeACLPermission.
    Add an interface to work with users and user groups data.
    Not all the openstack deployments use Keystone as Identity Service.
    So it is used here by default, but you can implement your own class depending
    on another Identity Service and specify it in the config.
    Implemented class should contains the following methods:
        * check_user_in_group(self, user_id, group_id);
        * check_user_is_admin(self, user_id, projects)
            checks if user is admin of any of projects in projects list;
        * get_user(self, subject)
            returns existing(means validated) user ID or 'everyone' key word,
            where subject can be user ID or name, or fails with NotFound
            exception;
        * get_group(self, subject)
            returns existing(means validated) group ID or 'everyone' key word,
            where subject is group ID, or fails with NotFound exception.
    Also you can use another implemented class, but there will be
    no functionality with user groups and admins.

    Note, that in a class for work through Keystone Identity Service
    v2.0 keystone client is used as well as v3 keystone client.
    It's due to some functions are implemented in the only version of
    keystone client, e.g. users.check_in_group is implemented in v3
    version only and then we should use v3 keystone client, but
    there is no roles.roles_for_user or any analogs in v3 version,
    in v2.0 only, then we should use v2.0 version for checking
    user(other user, not user_id from context) is admin.
    This will be fixed when it's possible.

levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish
a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a single user, a group of users, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission can be classifies as the following:

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
	Indicated as 1.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
	This permission includes Read permission.
	Indicated as 2.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
	Indicated as 3.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level. This permission includes Permission Read.
	Indicated as 4.
Read+Permission Read: Indicated as 5.
Write+Permission Read: Indicated as 6.
Full access: This permission inludes all the other permissions and
	equals to Write+Permission Write.
	Indicated as 7.
Read+Permission Write: Indicated as 8.

Implementation:

Part 2. Volume ACL Module
    Add CRUD for VolumeACLPermission.
    Add an interface to work with users and user groups data.
    Not all the openstack deployments use Keystone as Identity Service.
    So it is used here by default, but you can implement your own class depending
    on another Identity Service and specify it in the config.
    Implemented class should contains the following methods:
        * check_user_in_group(self, user_id, group_id);
        * check_user_is_admin(self, user_id, projects)
            checks if user is admin of any of projects in projects list;
        * get_user(self, subject)
            returns existing(means validated) user ID or 'everyone' key word,
            where subject can be user ID or name, or fails with NotFound
            exception;
        * get_group(self, subject)
            returns existing(means validated) group ID or 'everyone' key word,
            where subject is group ID, or fails with NotFound exception.
    Also you can use another implemented class, but there will be
    no functionality with user groups and admins.

    Note, that in a class for work through Keystone Identity Service
    v2.0 keystone client is used as well as v3 keystone client.
    It's due to some functions are implemented in the only version of
    keystone client, e.g. users.check_in_group is implemented in v3
    version only and then we should use v3 keystone client, but
    there is no roles.roles_for_user or any analogs in v3 version,
    in v2.0 only, then we should use v2.0 version for checking
    user(other user, not user_id from context) is admin.
    This will be fixed when it's possible.

blueprint volume-acl

", 'number': 7}, {'created': '2013-08-28 14:22:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Add Volume ACL Permissions: Volume ACL Module

ACL implementation brings a mechanism of access permission management into
Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,

The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission represents as an integer, which bits are mapped to:
1st(most significant) bit -- Permission Write;
2nd -- Permission Read;
3rd -- Write;
4th -- Read.
Where

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.

	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level.

commit_message:
Add Volume ACL Permissions: Volume ACL Module

Implementation:

Part 2. Volume ACL Module
    Add CRUD for VolumeACLPermission.
    Add an interface to work with users and user groups data.
    Not all the openstack deployments use Keystone as Identity Service.
    So you can implement your own class depending
    on another Identity Service and specify it in the config.
    Implemented class should contains the following methods:
        * check_user_in_group(self, user_id, group_id);
        * get_project(self, subject)
            returns existing(means validated) project ID or '*' key word
            for everyone,
            where subject can be user ID or name, or fails with NotFound
            exception;
        * get_group(self, subject)
            returns existing(means validated) group ID or '*' key word
            for everyone, where subject is group ID, or fails with
            NotFound exception.
    Also you can use another implemented class, but there will be
    no functionality with user groups and admins.

blueprint volume-acl

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-23 12:51:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Add Volume ACL Permissions: DB-related changes

ACL implementation brings a mechanism of access permission management into
Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,
which is full aceess(The user can do any operations on the volume.).
If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and
the users with super authoritzations, like administrators.
With ACL implementation, it is possible for different users to have different
levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish
a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a single user, a group of users, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission can be classifies as the following:

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
	Indicated as 1.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
	This permission includes Read permission.
	Indicated as 2.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
	Indicated as 3.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level. This permission includes Permission Read.
	Indicated as 4.
Read+Permission Read: Indicated as 5.
Write+Permission Read: Indicated as 6.
Full access: This permission inludes all the other permissions and
	equals to Write+Permission Write.
	Indicated as 7.
Read+Permission Write: Indicated as 8.

Implementation:

1. Add a new table called VolumeACLPermission with columns:
    id - the primary key of the row;
    volume_id - indicates volume's ID;
    user_or_group_id - indicates a user or group ID which the permission
    affects or 'everyone' keyword for all users;
    type - "user" means user_or_group_id is user_id; "group" means
    user_or_group_id is group_id;
    access_permission - indicates access permission level. (from 1 to 7 as
    described in Access Permission above)

    Use cases:
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Write access to user_id2. The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 1, volume_id: 'volume_id1', user_or_group_id: 'user_id2', type:
        'user', access_permission: 2}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read access to all users(everyone). The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 2, volume_id: 'volume_id1', user_or_group_id: 'everyone', type:
        'user', access_permission: 1}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read+Permission Read access to all the users
    in a group(group_id1). The corresponding record:
        {id: 3, volume_id: 'volume_id1', user_or_group_id: 'group_id1', type:
        'group', access_permission: 5}
2. CRUD for VolumeACLPermission.
3. Add os-volume-acl API extension.
    Use cases:
    * create/update permission:
        POST /v2/<project_id>/os-volume-acl
        {'body':
            'volume_acl_permission': {
                 'volume_id': <volume_id>,
                 'type': 'user', # or 'group'
                 'user_or_group_id': <user_or_group_id>,
                 'access_permission': <1-7>,
            }
        }
    * show permission (by permission ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>
    * list all permissions(for all the volumes for which the user has
    'Permission Read' access) or for a volume (by volume ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * get access permission level for the volume ID:
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/access?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * delete permission:
        DELETE /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>

blueprint volume-acl

Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,
which is full access(The user can do any operations on the volume.).
If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and
the users with super authoritzations, like administrators.
With ACL implementation, it is possible for different users to have different
levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish
a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a single user, a group of users, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission represents as an integer, which bits are mapped to:
1st(most significant) bit -- Permission Write;
2nd -- Permission Read;
3rd -- Write;
4th -- Read.
Where

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level.

Implementation:

Part 1. DB
    Add a new table called VolumeACLPermission with columns:
    id - the primary key of the row;
    volume_id - indicates volume's ID;
    entity_id - indicates a user or group ID which the permission
    affects or 'everyone' keyword for all users;
    type - "user" means entity_id is user_id; "group" means
    entity_id is group_id;
    access_permission - indicates access permission level. (as
    described in Access Permission above)

    Use cases:
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read+Write access to user_id2. The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 1, volume_id: 'volume_id1', entity_id: 'user_id2', type:
        'user', access_permission: 3}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read access to all users(everyone). The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 2, volume_id: 'volume_id1', entity_id: 'everyone', type:
        'user', access_permission: 1}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read+Permission Read access to all the users
    in a group(group_id1). The corresponding record:
        {id: 3, volume_id: 'volume_id1', entity_id: 'group_id1', type:
        'group', access_permission: 5}

blueprint volume-acl

commit_message:
Add Volume ACL Permissions: DB

ACL implementation brings a mechanism of access permission management into
Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,
which is full access(The user can do any operations on the volume.).
If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and
the users with super authorizations, like administrators.
With ACL implementation, it is possible for different users to have different
levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish
a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a group of users, users in a tenant, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission represents as an integer, which bits are mapped to:
1st (less significant) bit -- Read/Only attach;
2nd -- Read/Write attach;
3rd -- View Permissions;
4th -- Edit Permissions;
etc.

Where

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level.

Implementation:

Part 1. DB
    Add a new table called VolumeACLPermission with columns:
    id - the primary key of the row;
    volume_id - indicates volume's ID;
    entity_id - indicates group or project ID which the permission
    affects or '*' keyword for everyone;
    type - "project" means entity_id is project_id; "group" means
    entity_id is group_id;
    access_permission - indicates access permission level. (as
    described in Access Permission above)

    Use cases:
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read access to everyone. The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 2, volume_id: 'volume_id1', entity_id: '*', type:
        'project', access_permission: 1}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read+Permission Read access to all the users
    in a group(group_id1). The corresponding record:
        {id: 3, volume_id: 'volume_id1', entity_id: 'group_id1', type:
        'group', access_permission: 5}

blueprint volume-acl

Change-Id: I5e64247ff38c060a2278b3718205834d306f5028

commit_message:
Update iter_nodes to insert handoff when primay fail

WIP

When primary fails, the handoff will be shifted to fullfil the
node list. This would require lots of data moving when the
node rejoins the cluster in EC. By using 'insert' instead of
'shift' would save lots of work,

Change-Id: I16376e318abecd6bff4060fb832689259b8e4c2f

commit_message:
Add negative tests for subnet api

commit_message:
Fixing workbook events creation

* Workbook events creation is now called from a REST controller rather
 than from DB API. This is more proper place (level of abstraction).
* Fixed workbook definition controller and evets tests.

Change-Id: Ib17d0b0dae614c474c161cd12ecbb1b05aea74a8

commit_message:
Create-stack-user script should have execute permissions

Currently running stack.sh as root advises you about this script, which is not
executable

This is needed in stable/havana because grenade says to run this
version.

Change-Id: I674af044b8f3c31bcc86be5c6552e8086453d5cd
(cherry picked from commit 105c6e8718da2db50e48cb4a68be8522a80e101e)

commit_message:
API accepts only UUID for ports

The API currently accepts a MAC address in the URI query string for
ports, when it should only accept the port UUID. This is particular
unsuitable because the MAC address may change.

Change-Id: I78380e71ca9102206bed7f0fc6085726600293af
Closes-Bug: #1246816

subject: Use uppercase K for 1000 in oslo-incubator/openstack/common/units.py
revisions:
[{'created': '2014-01-01 23:49:29.000000000', 'files': ['openstack/common/units.py', 'tests/unit/test_units.py'], 'message': 'Use uppercase K for 1000 in oslo-incubator/openstack/common/units.py

In oslo, we are using lowercase k as variable for 1000, but using
uppercase M, G, T, P, E, Z, Y as variable for other unit variables.

It is better to update lowercase k to uppercase K as variable for
1000 to keep consistent.

Change-Id: I088fc9566f8d60b80914751bd6b13bd40a3528bd
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Use uppercase K for 1000 in oslo-incubator/openstack/common/units.py

In oslo, we are using lowercase k as variable for 1000, but using
uppercase M, G, T, P, E, Z, Y as variable for other unit variables.

It is better to update lowercase k to uppercase K as variable for
1000 to keep consistent.

Change-Id: I088fc9566f8d60b80914751bd6b13bd40a3528bd

commit_message:
Add missing quota flags in the config file sample

l3 extensions don't set quota flags in the config sample file
etc/neutron.conf.
Quota is unlimited if its value is minus and not only if it's -1.

Closes-Bug: #1250574
Change-Id: I76c8d1e2676d4e9b0feeed6e504e759fe736a0db
